Description: Alterations in RNA processing have recently emerged as a new cancer hallmark and a promising target for cancer therapies. Various steps in RNA processing, such as splicing and polyadenylation, are crucial for the correct expression of genes and are tightly controlled in normal cells. However, alterations of these RNA regulatory programs in cancer can lead to the dysregulation of gene expression that promotes tumor formation, metastasis, or drug resistance. Dysregulation of RNA processing can also impact tumor-immune interactions that unveil new therapeutic opportunities. Understanding the mechanisms underlying RNA regulation in health and disease will provide critical insights into the biology of cancer and should lead to the development of novel therapeutic approaches.
SearchResultBody: SY04. Targeting RNA Splicing in Cancer and the Immune System
Title: Targeting RNA Splicing in Cancer and the Immune System
